    "deletions": 4,
    "changes": 7,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Ftenant-restrictions-v2.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Ftenant-restrictions-v2.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fexternal-id%2Ftenant-restrictions-v2.md?ref=cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00",
    "patch": "@@ -265,10 +265,9 @@ Suppose you use tenant restrictions to block access by default, but you want to\n    > User granularity isn't supported with Microsoft accounts, so the **Select <organization> users and groups** capability isn't available. For other organizations, you could choose **Select <organization> users and groups**, and then perform these steps:\n    >\n    > 1. Select **Add external users and groups**.\n-   > 1. On the **Select** pane, enter the username or group name in the search box.\n-   > 1. Select the user or group in the search results.\n-   > 1. If you want to add more, select **Add** and repeat these steps.\n-   > 1. When you finish selecting the users and groups that you want to add, select **Submit**.\n+   > 1. In the **Add external user or group id** pane, type the object ID of the user or group you want to add.\n+   > 1. In the right dropdown, select whether it is a user or group.\n+   > 1. If you want to add more, select **Add** and repeat these steps. When you're done entering the users and groups you want to add, select **Submit**.\n \n 1. Select the **External applications** tab. Under **Access status**, choose whether to allow or block access to external applications:\n "
  },
  {
    "sha": "731783703d4e791b425057cd6855096c8f826887",
    "filename": "docs/fundamentals/copilot-security-entra-investigate-risky-apps.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 29,
    "deletions": 18,
    "changes": 47,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcopilot-security-entra-investigate-risky-apps.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcopilot-security-entra-investigate-risky-apps.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Ffundamentals%2Fcopilot-security-entra-investigate-risky-apps.md?ref=cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00",
    "patch": "@@ -5,7 +5,7 @@ keywords:\n author: shlipsey3\n ms.author: sarahlipsey\n manager: pmwongera\n-ms.date: 12/12/2024\n+ms.date: 09/05/2025\n ms.update-cycle: 180-days\n ms.topic: how-to\n ms.service: entra\n@@ -47,10 +47,11 @@ He uses any of the following prompts to get the information he needs:\n - *Are any apps at risk of being malicious or compromised?* \n - *List  5 apps with High Risk Level. Format the table as follows: Display Name | ID | Risk State* \n - *List the apps with Risk State “Confirmed compromise”.* \n-- *Show me the details of risky app with ID {ServicePrincipalObjectId} (or App ID {ApplicationId})* \n+- *Show me the details of risky app with ID {ServicePrincipalObjectId}*\n+- *Show me the details of risky app with AppID {ApplicationId})* \n \n->[!IMPORTANT]\n->You must use an account that is authorized to administer ID Protection for this skill to return risk information. Your tenant must also be licensed for [Workload Identities Premium](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/business/identity-access/microsoft-entra-workload-id#office-StandaloneSKU-k3hubfz).  \n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> You must use an account that is authorized to administer ID Protection for this skill to return risk information. Your tenant must also be licensed for [Workload Identities Premium](https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/business/identity-access/microsoft-entra-workload-id#office-StandaloneSKU-k3hubfz).  \n \n ### Explore Microsoft Entra service principals \n \n@@ -59,16 +60,18 @@ To get more information about these service principals identified as risky, Jaso\n He uses the following prompts to get the information he needs: \n \n - *Tell me more about these service principals (from previous response)* \n-- *Give me details about service principal with {DisplayName} (or {ServicePrincipalId})* \n-- *Give me a list of owners for these apps?* \n+- *Give me details about service principal with {DisplayName}*\n+- *Give me details about service principal with ID {ServicePrincipalObjectId})*\n+- *Give me a list of owners for these apps* \n \n ### Explore Microsoft Entra applications \n \n Jason also wants to understand more about the applications globally, such as details about the publisher and publisher verification status. \n \n Jason uses the following prompts to retrieve selected application properties:\n \n-- *Tell me more about the application {DisplayName} or {AppId}*\n+- *Tell me more about the application {DisplayName}*\n+- *Tell me more about the application with AppId {AppId}*\n - *Tell me more about these apps (from previous response)*\n \n ### View the permissions granted on a Microsoft Entra service principal \n@@ -77,12 +80,13 @@ Jason continues his assessment and wants to know what permissions were granted t\n \n Jason can also identify high privilege permissions granted on a service principal, based on Microsoft’s risk assessment. These are currently scoped to application permissions that generally enable tenant-wide access without user context and highly privileged Microsoft Entra administrator roles. \n \n->[!IMPORTANT]\n->This skill currently only looks at [API permissions](../identity-platform/permissions-consent-overview.md) and [Microsoft Entra administrator roles](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md). It doesn’t currently look at non-directory permissions granted in places like Azure RBAC or other authorization systems. High privileged permissions are limited to a static list of maintained by Microsoft that might evolve over time and it isn't currently viewable or customizable by customers. \n+> [!IMPORTANT]\n+> This skill currently only looks at [API permissions](../identity-platform/permissions-consent-overview.md) and [Microsoft Entra administrator roles](../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md). It doesn’t currently look at non-directory permissions granted in places like Azure RBAC or other authorization systems. High privileged permissions are limited to a static list of maintained by Microsoft that might evolve over time and it isn't currently viewable or customizable by customers.\n \n He uses the following prompts to get the permissions information he needs: \n \n-- *Which permissions are granted to the app with ID {ServicePrincipalId} or app ID {AppId}?*\n+- *Which permissions are granted to the app with ID {ServicePrincipalObjectId}?*\n+- *Which permissions are granted to the app with AppID {AppId}?*\n - *What permissions do the above risky apps have (from previous response)?*\n - *Which permissions granted to this app are highly privileged?*\n \n@@ -96,8 +100,8 @@ Jason realizes he has another “low hanging fruit” opportunity: to reduce ris\n \n Using the Copilot skill integrated with the existing [Microsoft Entra recommendation for unused apps](../identity/monitoring-health/recommendation-remove-unused-apps.md), Jason pulls the relevant data to investigate further or work with his team to improve their tenant security posture. The response includes links to specific apps for easier remediation.  The analyst can also ask about a specific app’s details directly in Security Copilot.  \n \n->[!NOTE]\n->The Copilot response returns a list of app registration or applications that are unused in past 90 days, which haven't been issued any tokens in that timeframe. \n+> [!NOTE]\n+> The Copilot response returns a list of app registration or applications that are unused in past 90 days, which haven't been issued any tokens in that timeframe. \n \n He uses the following prompts to get the information he needs: \n \n@@ -111,20 +115,27 @@ Jason would also like to look into the risk factor of external apps or multitena\n He uses the following prompts to get the information he needs: \n \n - *Show me apps outside my tenant* \n-- *How many apps are from outside my tenant?* \n+- *How many apps are from outside my tenant?*\n+\n+### Explore Microsoft Entra Application consent behavior\n+\n+Jason would like to know about the consent behavior of the apps in his tenant, especially those he had identified as risky or from outside his tenant. Understanding this behavior is especially important with the risk of [consent phishing attacks](../identity/enterprise-apps/protect-against-consent-phishing.md), which trick users into granting permissions to malicious cloud applications. Determining who granted consent to a potentially malicious app or looking at trends in consent failures can be an important clue to identify and remediate these attacks.\n+\n+He uses the following prompts to get the information he needs: \n+\n+- *Who granted consent to app with ID {ServicePrincipalObjectId}?* \n+- *Show me any failed application consent requests in the last week*\n \n ## Remediate\n \n By using Security Copilot, Jason is able to gather comprehensive risk and basic information about the applications and service principals in their Microsoft Entra tenant. After Jason completes his assessment, he takes action to remediate the risky applications. Security Copilot surfaces links to the Microsoft Entra admin center in responses for administrators to take the appropriate remediation actions. \n \n He reads about [managing access and security for applications](../identity/enterprise-apps/tutorial-manage-access-security.md), [security workload identities](../id-protection/concept-workload-identity-risk.md), [protecting against consent phishing](../identity/enterprise-apps/protect-against-consent-phishing.md), and [response playbooks](/security/operations/incident-response-playbook-compromised-malicious-app) to determine possible actions to take next. \n \n-## Next steps\n+## Related content\n \n-Learn more about: \n - [Manage application access and security](../identity/enterprise-apps/tutorial-manage-access-security.md)\n-- What is risk in ID Protection? \n - [Securing workload identities with Microsoft Entra ID Protection](../id-protection/concept-workload-identity-risk.md)\n-- [Protect against consent phishing - Microsoft Entra ID | Microsoft Learn](../identity/enterprise-apps/protect-against-consent-phishing.md) \n+- [Protect against consent phishing](../identity/enterprise-apps/protect-against-consent-phishing.md) \n - [Compromised and malicious applications investigation](/security/operations/incident-response-playbook-compromised-malicious-app) \n-- [Respond to identity threats using risky user summarization](copilot-entra-risky-user-summarization.md)\n+- [Respond to identity threats using risky user summarization](copilot-entra-risky-user-summarization.md)\n\\ No newline at end of file"
  },

    "patch": "@@ -63,7 +63,7 @@ To see a detailed summary of the agent's activity, the recommendations (approve\n \n The **Summary of agent activity** is a natural language description of the activity illustrated in the **Agent activity map**. These details help you understand the logic behind the agent and you can view the recommendations and justification summaries on the last card in the activity map.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-agent-review-card-justification.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of Access Review Agent justification in activity card.\" lightbox=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-agent-review-card-justification.png\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-agent-review-card-justification.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of access agent review card justification.\" lightbox=\"media/access-review-agent-logs-metrics/access-agent-review-card-justification.png\":::\n \n \n ## Related content"
  },
  {
    "sha": "8aa0f07232b8646c78ddd0cd205be7c4a48d4418",
    "filename": "docs/id-governance/access-review-agent.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 3,
    "deletions": 0,
    "changes": 3,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fid-governance%2Faccess-review-agent.md?ref=cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00",
    "patch": "@@ -56,6 +56,9 @@ The following tables show current Access Review Agent support based on review sc\n |Group owners     |  :white_check_mark:        |\n |Managers     |  :white_check_mark:        |\n |Self-reviews     |  ❌    |\n+|**Languages**  |  |\n+|English     |   :white_check_mark:       |\n+|Other languages     |  ❌       |\n \n ## How it works\n The Access Review Agent proactively scans for active access reviews in your tenant that are flagged for processing by the agent. The agent then analyzes identified reviews by gathering extra insights, and generates a recommendation (approve / deny) and a justification summary for each decision. Once the agent analyzes the recommendations and corresponding justification summaries, it's able to guide reviewers, in natural language, through the review process in Microsoft Teams. Reviewers are empowered to complete their reviews through the natural language chat experience in Microsoft Teams. As the agent guides them through the review, they're able to review the agent's reasoning behind the recommendations, ask questions in the context of the review itself, and finally make their own informed decision."
  },

    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fmedia%2Faccess-review-agent-logs-metrics%2Faccess-agent-review-card-justification.png",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fid-governance%2Fmedia%2Faccess-review-agent-logs-metrics%2Faccess-agent-review-card-justification.png",

    "sha": "de7942217420fc9f05e604c64a3a2d6efe8abef6",
    "filename": "docs/identity/conditional-access/TOC.yml",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 0,
    "deletions": 2,
    "changes": 2,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2FTOC.yml",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2FTOC.yml",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2FTOC.yml?ref=cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00",
    "patch": "@@ -16,8 +16,6 @@\n     href: agent-optimization-logs-metrics.md\n   - name: Phased rollout\n     href: agent-optimization-phased-rollout.md\n-  - name: Optimization agent FAQ\n-    href: agent-optimization-faq.yml\n - name: Tutorials\n   items:\n   - name: Require multifactor authentication"
  },
  {
    "sha": "07d1c53fd8143aadaed8d45b5ca6304c91ca4783",
    "filename": "docs/identity/conditional-access/agent-optimization-phased-rollout.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 54,
    "deletions": 35,
    "changes": 89,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization-phased-rollout.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization-phased-rollout.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization-phased-rollout.md?ref=cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00",
    "patch": "@@ -6,87 +6,106 @@ author: shlipsey3\n manager: pmwongera\n \n ms.reviewer: lhuangnorth\n-ms.date: 08/12/2025\n+ms.date: 08/28/2025\n \n ms.service: entra-id\n ms.subservice: conditional-access\n ms.topic: concept-article\n ms.custom: security-copilot\n ms.collection: msec-ai-copilot\n ---\n-# Conditional Access optimization agent phased rollout (preview)\n+# Conditional Access optimization agent phased rollout\n \n-The Conditional Access optimization agent for Microsoft Entra includes a preview phased rollout capability that helps organizations deploy new Conditional Access policies safely and efficiently. This Microsoft Security Copilot feature in Microsoft Entra enables administrators to introduce policies gradually, monitor their impact, and minimize disruptions. There are several benefits to this phased rollout capability:\n-\n-- **User impact mitigation**: Gradual deployment minimizes the chance of widespread disruption to end users.\n-- **Operational efficiency**: Reduces the need for manual analysis and planning, saving weeks of effort.\n-- **Customization**: Administrators retain full control over group selection and rollout pacing.\n-- **Transparency**: The agent provides clear reasoning for group assignments and rollout decisions.\n+The Conditional Access optimization agent for Microsoft Entra includes a phased rollout capability that helps organizations deploy new Conditional Access policies safely and efficiently. This Microsoft Security Copilot feature in Microsoft Entra enables administrators to introduce policies gradually, monitor their impact, and minimize disruptions. This phased rollout capability provides gradual deployment of new policies to minimize the chance of widespread disruption to end users and reduce the need for manual analysis and planning, saving weeks of effort. As with all aspects of the Conditional Access Optimization Agent, administrators retain full control of the policy changes, such as group selection and rollout pacing. Clear reasoning for the rollout plan is also provided to maintain transparency.\n \n This article explains how the phased rollout process works, outlines prerequisites, and describes the built-in safeguards that help ensure a smooth deployment.\n \n-> [!IMPORTANT]\n-> The phased rollout capability in the Conditional Access Optimization agent is currently in PREVIEW.\n-> This information relates to a prerelease product that might be substantially modified before release. Microsoft makes no warranties, expressed or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\n-\n ## Prerequisites\n \n - You must have at least the [Microsoft Entra ID P1](overview.md#license-requirements) license.\n - You must have available [security compute units (SCU)](/copilot/security/manage-usage).\n-- [Global Reader](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-reader) and [Security Reader](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-reader) roles can view the agent and any suggestions, but can't take any actions.\n-- [Global Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-administrator), [Security Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-administrator), and [Conditional Access Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator) roles can view the agent and take action on the suggestions.\n+- [Security Reader](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-reader) and [Global Reader](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-reader) roles can view the agent and any suggestions, but can't take any actions.\n+- [Conditional Access Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#conditional-access-administrator), [Security Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-administrator), and [Global Administrator](../../identity/role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#global-administrator) roles can view the agent and take action on the suggestions.\n+- Tenants must have at least five defined groups that are currently used in Conditional Access policies for the agent to generate a phased rollout plan.\n \n ## How it works\n \n-When the Conditional Access optimization agent creates a new policy in report-only mode, it can suggest turning on the policy with a phased rollout. The agent analyzes sign-in data and existing policies to define a phased rollout plan. There are three main steps in the phased rollout process.\n+When the Conditional Access optimization agent creates a new policy in report-only mode, it can suggest turning on the policy with a phased rollout. The agent analyzes sign-in data and existing policies to define a phased rollout plan.\n+\n+Policies that are intended to apply to *all users* and need to be turned on are eligible for a phased rollout. Because there are five distinct phases to a rollout plan, you must have at least five groups for the rollout plan to apply. To determine which groups to use, the agent looks at groups that were previously or are currently used in Conditional Access policies. The agent looks at those groups to see how other Conditional Access policies affected them, to gauge potential impact. The agent looks at the size of the groups and then uses all these factors to assign the groups to the phases starting with the low impact groups and ending with the higher-impact groups.\n+\n+There are three steps in the phased rollout process:\n \n-### Agent creates a report-only policy with a phased rollout\n+1. [Agent creates a report-only policy with a phased rollout](#agent-creates-a-report-only-policy-with-a-phased-rollout)\n+1. [Administrator reviews, edits, and accepts the rollout plan](#administrator-reviews-edits-and-accepts-the-rollout-plan)\n+1. [Agent or Administrator executes the approved rollout plan](#agent-or-administrator-executes-the-approved-rollout-plan)\n+\n+You can review the groups included in each phase and the number of days between each phase and make changes before and during the phased rollout. At any time during the rollout, you can choose to have the plan executed by the agent or you can manually execute each phase of the plan.\n+\n+Regardless of how the plan is executed or if you made changes to the plan, when the first phase starts, a *new* policy is created and turned on for the groups included in the first phase. The original report-only mode policy remains intact.\n+\n+## Agent creates a report-only policy with a phased rollout\n \n The agent creates a report-only policy and builds a separate phased rollout plan. The rollout plans include five phases, starting with small, low-risk groups and progressing to larger, high-risk groups.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-policy-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a phased rollout policy suggestion.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-policy-details.png\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-suggestions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the agent suggestions with a phased rollout type highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-suggestions-expanded.png\":::\n \n-### Administrator reviews and accepts the rollout plan\n+In the list of suggestions from the agent, look for **Suggested phased rollout** in the **Actions taken by agent** column.\n \n-Administrators review the details of the plan and can accept it or modify the group assignments or the time between phases.\n+### Administrator reviews, edits, and accepts the rollout plan\n \n-To adjust the groups included in a phase:\n+Administrators need to review the details of the plan, including the groups included in each phase, the timing of each phase, and how the plan will be executed.\n \n 1. Sign in to the [Microsoft Entra admin center](https://entra.microsoft.com) as at least a [Security Administrator](../role-based-access-control/permissions-reference.md#security-administrator).\n \n 1. Browse to **Conditional Access Optimization Agent** and select the **Review suggestions** button for a policy suggestion that includes a phased rollout.\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-suggestions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the agent suggestions with a phased rollout type highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-suggestions-expanded.png\":::\n-\n 1. From the policy details page, select **Review phases**.\n \n-1. Select the pencil icon to edit the groups included in the phase.\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-review-phases-button.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a phased rollout policy suggestion.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-review-phases-button.png\":::\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-review-phases.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phases that can be edited.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-review-phases.png\":::\n+1. Select **Edit Groups** to edit the groups included in the phase.\n \n-1. Edit the groups by either adding or removing them from the phase. Select the **Select** button to save the changes.\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-edit-groups-button.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phases that can be edited with the edit groups button highlighted.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-edit-groups-button.png\":::\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-group-edit.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phase group edit options.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-group-edit.png\":::\n+1. Select the down arrow on the **Automatically roll out phases** button to select an execution mode.\n+    - **Automatically roll out phases**: Agent automatically rolls out each phase, based on timing and impact signals.\n+    - **Manually roll out phases**: Administrator manually advances each phase of the rollout.\n \n-1. Select **Apply suggestion** to save the changes to the groups and accept the rollout plan.\n+    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-execution-mode-button.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the option to change execution mode.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-execution-mode-button.png\":::\n+\n+> [!TIP]\n+> You can intervene at any time with automatic and manual rollout plans. You can also change execution modes at any time during rollout.\n \n To adjust the time between phases:\n \n-1. From the Conditional Access Optimization Agent page, select the **Settings** tab. \n+1. Browse to the **Settings** tab from the Conditional Access Optimization Agent.\n 1. Adjust the days between phases in the **Phased rollout** section.\n 1. Select the **Save** button to apply the changes.\n \n-For more information, review the [Phased rollout settings](agent-optimization.md#phased-rollout-preview).\n+For more information, review the [Phased rollout settings](agent-optimization.md#phased-rollout).\n+\n+## Agent or administrator executes the approved rollout plan\n+\n+The options available to manage the phased rollout are different for automatic and manual execution.\n+\n+### Automatically roll out phases\n+\n+If you selected automatic rollout, the agent automatically executes the plan by creating a new, enabled policy that applies to all groups in the first phase. Once the rollout starts, several controls appear to manage the rollout.\n+\n+The agent deploys the policy to the groups in the next phases based on the defined schedule. At any time during the phased rollout, you can pause the execution of the plan or choose to manually roll out the remaining phases.\n+\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-automatic-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of an automatically executed phased rollout.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-automatic-details.png\":::\n \n-### Agent executes the approved rollout plan\n+You can continue to monitor between each phase of the rollout to ensure the policy does what's expected. While the policy is being rolled out, the original report-only policy remains in report-only mode for the remaining phases. After the phased rollout is complete, the agent recommends deleting the report-only policy the next time it runs, so you can maintain a clean policy list.\n \n-The agent automatically executes the plan by creating a new, enabled policy that applies to all groups in the first phase. The original report-only policy remains intact so you can continue to collect data on the policy.\n+### Manually roll out phases\n \n-The agent deploys the policy to the groups in the next phases based on the defined schedule. You can continue to monitor between each phase of the rollout to ensure the policy does what's expected. While the policy is being rolled out, the policy remains in report-only mode for the remaining phases. \n+If you chose to manually execute the phased rollout plan, you're provided several options to manage each step.\n \n-:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-in-progress.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a phased rollout that's in progress.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-in-progress.png\":::\n+:::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-manual-details.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of a phased rollout plan in manual execution mode.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization-phased-rollout/phased-rollout-manual-details.png\":::\n \n-After every phase is complete, the agent will recommend deleting the report-only policy the next time it runs, so you can maintain a clean policy list.\n+You must select the **Move to next phase** to advance each phase of the rollout. At any phase, you can revert to the previous phase or opt to have the agent automatically roll out the remaining phases.\n \n ## Built-in safeguards\n \n@@ -96,7 +115,7 @@ Once the phased rollout begins, you can't update the policy's grant controls. If\n \n ### How does the phased rollout capability work?\n \n-After selecting the groups that each phase will apply to, the agent creates a duplicate Conditional Access policy that only includes the group of the first phase. The original Conditional Access policy persists in report-only mode and targets all users, so you can continue to collect data. When the deployment advances to the next phase, the batch of groups is added to the enabled Conditional Access policy. The agent monitors how each stage affects the sign-ins associated with this policy. If the success rate drops below 90%, the phased rollout stops and the enabled policy is placed back into report-only mode. You can then review the logs to determine why sign-ins were failing before attempting the phased rollout again.\n+After selecting the groups that each phase applies to, the agent creates a duplicate Conditional Access policy that only includes the group of the first phase. The original Conditional Access policy persists in report-only mode and targets all users, so you can continue to collect data. When the deployment advances to the next phase, the batch of groups is added to the enabled Conditional Access policy. The agent monitors how each stage affects the sign-ins associated with this policy. If the success rate drops below 90%, the phased rollout stops and the enabled policy is placed back into report-only mode. You can then review the logs to determine why sign-ins were failing before attempting the phased rollout again.\n \n ### Do I have to turn on phased rollout?\n "
  },
  {
    "sha": "3302ba698022bada22c3a04350824c23791952f4",
    "filename": "docs/identity/conditional-access/agent-optimization.md",
    "status": "modified",
    "additions": 14,
    "deletions": 6,
    "changes": 20,
    "blob_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/blob/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization.md",
    "raw_url": "https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/raw/cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization.md",
    "contents_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/MicrosoftDocs/entra-docs/contents/docs%2Fidentity%2Fconditional-access%2Fagent-optimization.md?ref=cbac067e3847353c7132c31656c08ea56cd0aa00",
    "patch": "@@ -6,7 +6,7 @@ author: MicrosoftGuyJFlo\n manager: dougeby\n ms.reviewer: lhuangnorth\n \n-ms.date: 08/12/2025\n+ms.date: 08/28/2025\n \n ms.update-cycle: 180-days\n ms.service: entra-id\n@@ -22,7 +22,7 @@ The Conditional Access optimization agent helps you ensure all users and applica\n The Conditional Access optimization agent evaluates policies such as requiring multifactor authentication (MFA), enforcing device based controls (device compliance, app protection policies, and domain-joined devices), and blocking legacy authentication and device code flow. The agent also evaluates all existing enabled policies to propose potential consolidation of similar policies. When the agent identifies a suggestion, you can have the agent update the associated policy with one click-remediation.\n \n > [!IMPORTANT]\n-> The chat capability in the Conditional Access optimization agent is currently in PREVIEW.\n+> The chat capability and policy reports in the Conditional Access optimization agent are currently in PREVIEW.\n > This information relates to a prerelease product that might be substantially modified before release. Microsoft makes no warranties, expressed or implied, with respect to the information provided here.\n \n ## Prerequisites\n@@ -38,7 +38,6 @@ The Conditional Access optimization agent evaluates policies such as requiring m\n    - For more information, see [Assign Security Copilot access](/copilot/security/authentication#assign-security-copilot-access).\n - Device-based controls require [Microsoft Intune licenses](/intune/intune-service/fundamentals/licenses).\n - Review [Privacy and data security in Microsoft Security Copilot](/copilot/security/privacy-data-security).\n-\n    \n ### Limitations\n \n@@ -78,6 +77,7 @@ The policy suggestions identified by the agent include:\n - **Risky users**: The agent suggests a policy to require secure password change for high risk users. Requires Microsoft Entra ID P2 license.\n - **Risky sign-ins**: The agent suggests a policy to require multifactor authentication for high risk sign-ins. Requires Microsoft Entra ID P2 license.\n - **Policy consolidation**: The agent scans your policy and identifies overlapping settings. For example, if you have more than one policy that has the same grant controls, the agent suggests consolidating those policies into one.\n+- **Deep analysis**: The agent looks at policies that correspond to key scenarios to identify outlier policies that have more than a recommended number of exceptions (leading to unexpected gaps in coverage) or no exceptions (leading to possible lockout). \n \n > [!IMPORTANT]\n > The agent doesn't make any changes to existing policies unless an administrator explicitly approves the suggestion.\n@@ -132,11 +132,11 @@ Use the checkboxes under **Microsoft Entra objects to monitor** to specify what\n \n By default, the Conditional Access optimization agent can create new policies in report-only mode. You can change this setting so that an administrator must approve the new policy before it's created. The policy is still created in report-only mode, but only after admin approval. After reviewing the policy impact, you can turn on the policy directly from the agent experience or from Conditional Access.\n \n-### Phased rollout (preview)\n+### Phased rollout\n \n When the agent creates a new policy in report-only mode, the policy is rolled out in phases, so you can control and monitor the effect of the new policy. Phased rollout is on by default.\n \n-You can change the number of days between each phase by either dragging the slider or entering a number of days in the text box. After making any changes, select the **Save** button at the bottom of the page. The number of days between each phase is the same for all phases. Make sure you're starting the phased rollout with enough time to monitor the impact before the next phase starts and so the rollout doesn't start on a weekend or holiday, in case you need to pause the rollout.\n+You can change the number of days between each phase by either dragging the slider or entering a number in the text box. After making any changes, select the **Save** button at the bottom of the page. The number of days between each phase is the same for all phases. Make sure you're starting the phased rollout with enough time to monitor the impact before the next phase starts and so the rollout doesn't start on a weekend or holiday, in case you need to pause the rollout.\n \n :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/phased-rollout-settings.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the phased rollout settings in the Conditional Access Optimization agent settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/phased-rollout-settings.png\":::\n \n@@ -150,7 +150,7 @@ There are several key points to consider regarding the identity and permissions\n - The user who approves a suggestion to add users to a policy becomes an owner of a new group that adds the users to a policy. \n - The audit logs for actions taken by the agent are associated with the user who enabled the agent. You can find the name of the account that started the agent in the **Identity and permissions** section of the settings.\n \n-    :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/identity-permissions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the identity and permissions section in the Conditional Access Optimization agent settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/identity-permissions.png\":::\n+   :::image type=\"content\" source=\"media/agent-optimization/identity-permissions.png\" alt-text=\"Screenshot of the identity and permissions section in the Conditional Access Optimization agent settings.\" lightbox=\"media/agent-optimization/identity-permissions.png\":::\n \n ### Custom instructions\n \n@@ -174,6 +174,14 @@ For more information about how to use custom instructions, check out the followi\n \n Please note that some of the content in the video, such as the user interface elements, is subject to change as the agent is updated frequently.\n \n+## Intune integration\n+\n+The Conditional Access Optimization Agent integrates with Microsoft Intune to monitor application protection policies configured in Intune and identify potential gaps in Conditional Access enforcement. This proactive and automated approach ensures that Conditional Access policies remain aligned with organizational security goals and compliance requirements. The agent suggestions are the same as the other policy suggestions, except that Intune provides part of the signal to the agent.\n+\n+Agent suggestions for Intune scenarios cover specific user groups and platforms (iOS or Android). For example, the agent identifies an active Intune app protection policy that targets the \"Finance\" group, but determines there isn't a sufficient Conditional Access policy that enforces app protection. The agent creates a report-only policy that requires users to access resources only through compliant applications on iOS devices.\n+\n+The agent must be running as a Security Administrator or Global Administrator to identify Intune app protection policies. The Conditional Access Administrator role doesn't have sufficient privileges in Intune.\n+\n ## Remove agent\n \n If you no longer wish to use the Conditional Access optimization agent, select **Remove agent** from the top of the agent window. The existing data (agent activity, suggestions, and metrics) is removed but any policies created or updated based on the agent suggestions remain intact. Previously applied suggestions remain unchanged so you can continue to use the policies created or modified by the agent."
  },

ai_summary.Response:
The document updates primarily focus on enhancing clarity and accuracy across several Microsoft Entra documentation pages.

Firstly, changes have been made to the "Tenant Restrictions v2" documentation, refining the steps for adding external users and groups.

Secondly, the "Copilot for Security with Microsoft Entra ID" documentation has been significantly updated, with a focus on improving the prompts and examples for investigating risky applications and service principals. The date has also been advanced.

Thirdly, minor edits have been made to the "Access Review Agent Logs and Metrics" and "Access Review Agent" documentation, including an image alt-text correction and the addition of language support information for the agent.

Finally, extensive revisions have been made to the "Conditional Access optimization agent phased rollout" documentation. This includes removing the "preview" label, expanding on the phased rollout process, adding new screenshots, and detailing the automatic and manual execution of rollout plans. Additionally, the "Conditional Access optimization agent" documentation has been updated to reflect the removal of the "preview" label for chat capabilities, the addition of "deep analysis" as a suggestion type, and the inclusion of Intune integration details. Minor adjustments have also been made to the TOC.
